contentrichtext.text: [[File:Marion Tinsley.jpg|thumb|right|Grandmaster Tinsley]] '''Marion Tinsley''' (February 3, 1927 – April 3, 1995) is considered the greatest [[English draughts|checkers]] player who ever lived. He was world champion from 1955–1958 and 1975–1991. Tinsley never lost a World Championship match, and lost only seven games (two of them to the [[Chinook (draughts player)|Chinook computer program]]) in his entire 45 year career.<ref name="HumanPerfection">{{cite web|url=http://www.wylliedraughts.com/Tinsley.htm|title=Marion Tinsley: Human Perfection at Checkers?|author=Jonathan Schaeffer|authorlink=Jonathan Schaeffer}}</ref> He withdrew from championship play during the years 1958–1975, relinquishing the title during that time. ==Vs. Chinook== Tinsley retired from championship play in 1991. In August 1992, he defeated the [[Chinook Checkers Program|Chinook computer program]] 4–2 (with 33 draws) in a match. Chinook had placed second at the U.S. Nationals in 1990, which usually qualifies one to compete for a national title. However, the [[American Checker Federation|American Checkers Federation]] and the [[English Draughts Association]] refused to allow a computer to play for the title. Unable to appeal their decision, Tinsley resigned his title as World Champion and immediately indicated his desire to play against Chinook. The unofficial yet highly publicized match was quickly organized, and was won by Tinsley. In one game, Chinook, playing with white pieces, made a mistake on the tenth move. Tinsley remarked, "You're going to regret that." Chinook resigned after move 36, fully 26 moves later. The lead programmer Schaeffer looked back into the database and discovered that Tinsley picked the only strategy that could have defeated Chinook from that point and Tinsley was able to see the win 64 moves into the future. <ref>[http://www.msri.org/publications/books/Book29/files/schaeffer.pdf] [[Jonathan Schaeffer]] and Robert Lake. "Solving the Game of Checkers." ''[[Games of No Chance]]'', vol. 29, 1996, p. 129-130.</ref><ref name="king"> http://yellowmagpie.com/dr-marion-tinsley-draughts/: "Dr Marion Tinsley: The Checkers Mathematician", YellowMagpie</ref> The ACF and the EDA were placed in the awkward position of naming a new world champion, a title which would be worthless as long as Tinsley was alive. The ACF granted Tinsley the title of World Champion Emeritus as a solution. In August 1994, a second match with Chinook was organized, but Tinsley withdrew after only six games (all draws) for health reasons. [[Don Lafferty]], rated the number two player in the world at the time, replaced Tinsley and fought Chinook to a draw. Tinsley was diagnosed with [[pancreatic cancer]] a week later. Seven months later, he died. ==Education== He is sometimes listed as "Dr. Marion Tinsley" because he had a doctorate in mathematics and worked as a professor of mathematics at [[Florida State University]] and [[Florida A&M University]]. Tinsley once claimed to have spent approximately ten thousand hours studying checkers while in graduate school. Tinsley also served as a [[Baptist]] minister.<ref name="HumanPerfection"/> ==Television appearances== In 1957, he appeared as a guest challenger on the [[television]] [[game show]] ''[[To Tell the Truth]]''. ==World Championship titles== *7 time world champion (Three-move): 1955, 1958, 1979, 1981, 1985, 1987, 1989 *1 time world champion (Two-move): 1952<ref>http://www.usacheckers.com/worldchampionshipresults.php</ref> ==See also== *[[List of draughts players]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.cs.ualberta.ca/~chinook/people/Tinsley.php University of Alberta article on Tinsley] *{{MathGenealogy|id=10157}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Tinsley, Marion | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American checkers player | DATE OF BIRTH = 3 February 1927 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Ironton, Ohio | DATE OF DEATH = 3 April 1995 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tinsley, Marion}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:American checkers players]] [[Category:Players of English draughts]] [[Category:Baptists from the United States]] [[Category:Florida State University faculty]]
